head.title: Separatists Blamed for Attacks in India State

hedline.hl1: Separatists Blamed for Attacks in India State
hedline.hl2: Separatists Blamed for Attacks in Northern India

abstract.p: United Liberation Front of Assam is suspected in deaths of at least 67 people in attacks in India's troubled northeastern state of Assam; most of dead are Hindi-speaking settlers; group has been fighting for independence since 1979 and for expulsion of non-Assamese workers who came from outside region (S)

block.p: At least 67 people have been killed in the past four days in attacks in India's troubled northeastern state of Assam. Most of the dead are Hindi-speaking settlers who migrated to the area for work decades ago.

The police suspect that a separatist rebel group, the United Liberation Front of Assam, is behind the attacks. The group has been fighting since 1979 for independence and for the expulsion of non-Assamese workers who came from outside the region of Assam, the oil-rich and tea-producing state near the Myanmar border.
It was the worst violence in the region in years, and hundreds of workers were fleeing the area.

The police suspect that a separatist rebel group, the United Liberation Front of Assam, is behind the attacks. The group has been fighting since 1979 for independence and for the expulsion of non-Assamese workers who came from outside the region of Assam, the oil-rich and tea-producing state near the Myanmar border.
Peace talks with the government failed in September, and the government resumed counterinsurgency efforts against the rebels.
Assam's police chief, R. N. Mathur, said, ''We are patrolling the area heavily, and the situation is tense but under control.''
It was the worst violence in the region in years, and hundreds of workers were fleeing the area, the authorities said.
The authorities imposed a round-the-clock curfew in the affected districts and sent out police and paramilitary patrols.
